title: Ivan Seliminski
text:
Dr. Ivan Seliminski (1799 – 1866) was a prominent <a href="Bulgarian%20people">Bulgarian</a> philosopher, scholar, teacher and medical doctor.
Education.
He was born in <a href="Sliven">Sliven</a> in 1799. Later, he took the name of this town as his surname. His early school years were spent in a Greek school in Sliven. His secondary education was in Kidonia. He traveled in <a href="Europe">Europe</a>.
Teacher.
Seliminski returned to Sliven in 1825. He opened a school in which he taught physics. His school became one of the first Bulgarian lower-level secondary schools.
Evacuation in Bessarabia.
On the eve of the <a href="Russo-Turkish%20War%20%281828%E2%80%931829%29">Russian-Turkish War</a> (1828–1829) he organized many Bulgarians to support the Russian army. With the creation of revolutionary organizations in Sliven and some other cities, Seliminski became the first major Bulgarian revolutionary. After the war Seliminski participated in Russian delegations. Many Bulgarian people left their homes and emigrated to the other side of the <a href="Danube">Danube</a> in Vlahia. Ivan Seliminski opened a school and was a teacher in New Sliven (now Berjazka) and <a href="Bucharest">Bucharest</a>.
Medical doctor.
From 1840 to 1844 Seliminski studied medicine in <a href="Athens">Athens</a>. After that he traveled to <a href="Paris">Paris</a> (1845) and practiced as a medical doctor in Bucharest, <a href="Braila">Braila</a> and <a href="Bessarabia">Bessarabia</a> until the end of his life (1845–1866).
